review_title: Great place to learn and accelerate your career
pros:
-Great culture, politicking is almost non-existent, people are genuinely friendly and care for your well-being

-1 year at ShopBack gives you 3 years worth of learning and experience at other companies; you will find that you've grown a lot and are ready to take on tougher challenges at a pace you didn't think likely before

-Career progression here is non-linear; if you do well enough, regardless of your age or years of experience, you will find yourself being promoted very quickly

-Retention rate is much higher compared to other tech companies, other than the new joiners, most of the people here have been around for 4-5 years (the company is only 7 years old)

-High-caliber colleagues; this is of course dependent on the team itself but most people I've interacted with are pretty smart. Says a lot about the company that for the good performers who do end up leaving, most of them end up in global tech giants like FAANG for example

-Stock value has multiplied several times in the past few years, which also explains the high retention rate and spurs people to work harder
cons:
-Not for everyone because of how fast-paced the company is, everyone is expected to carry their own weight and then some, definitely not someplace you can chill and still expect to be an average performer

-Benefits are not great, insurance and allowances while decent are still below that of other comparable tech companies

review_title: Not a place for the weak
pros:
- fast-growing startup (proof - country expansion and team expansion all the time)
- friendly, curious and hard working people all around
- can learn and test new technologies without constraints as long as it adds value to the company (proof - internal tools)
- culture of excellence - mentality of getting better and better
- culture of learning - HR and founders encourage to learn and grow. (proof - in office library with awesome books and reviews)
- friendly founders and management team - they are more than willing to listen your problems and help you if you have problems and approach them. However, please bear in mind that they are not mind reader and they are still human with 24 hours a day. So, you really need to approach them and communicate your issues. Do not expect they know every single items. That's not their job. Their job is to hire good people, drive the whole team to a common goal with the most efficient way, resource, and time. 
- Advice for current and potential employees - talk to founders and management. They are really friendly but they do not take BS. The amount and type of help they can give individually or as a team is tremendous and I cannot stress this anymore.  You spent more than 1/3 of your 24 hours in office. Don't be stranger. Talk to them.
cons:
- long working hour - However, this is not mandatory and this is not every day. Read how the best athletes and companies build their brand. Do you think Apple's, Amazon's and Alibaba's employees get to their place by just working 9-5 sharp, go home, chill and partying weekends? If you think so, you are really in the wrong place. ShopBackers (ShopBack employees) party like crazy but they work hard when need to.
- Communication across the company - this needs a long-term solution. With the company this size growing super fast with lots of new people and teams, definitely, communication and binding all of them to a common and single goal are challenging and huge tasks.
- Pay - may not be the best if you are just counting the $$$. However, what they can provide is more than $$$. Learning, personal and professional growth, networks, awesome people, free flow of beer and drinks and snacks, parties are a few of them.

review_title: Nice on the outside, not so on the inside
pros:
Had good people working, however each of them left over time.

Salary is considered on the low side, but perks were okay.

Recognition is okay.
cons:
People Management
- The first reason why I left, no one were actually concentrating on the people. Burnouts, work overload, etc. Yes there are initiatives to tackle these like 'managers being open', talk sessions, etc, but no actual solutions per se. Most of us felt that ShopBack doing all these were just to say 'Hey, we did try to help.' but in reality its just BS. Solution: Allocate work properly, and when someone provides feedback, work on a SOLUTION rather than just 'talk' about it. Talk is cheap.

Work Allocation
- Yes its a startup, and its hectic mostly, but most of the time those that does work fast would be victim of more work allocated. Some managers would actually take advantage of this, and yes the said employee would get a good yearly review, but for a year for proper recognition? Dont get me started on the increment - not worth it for anyone to go the extra mile every day. End up most of us just go the extra mile once in a while to make sure we're in the 'game'.

Career Growth vs Salary
- Those that actually worked hard, and managed to get promoted, salary increment is actually not on par to meet market salary. There were situations (please take note, its plural), where new joiners had higher salary package compared to current employees - yes the new joiner had more experience, but most of the time work quality is for the dumps. Some do get good growth, but they typically dont comment much as they would just use it to update their CV so that they can go elsewhere with better pay.

review_title: Best place for high achievers but bad place for ppl who just want stable working hrs
pros:
- Cool & talented colleagues from various countries in Asia who are sincere to be your friends. Almost no politics observed
- Very driven working environment. Everyone is willing to go for extra mile to achieve target. Performance based, no favourtism/hierarchy
- Weekly & monthly check-in with manager for both work progress and feedback. Great open culture
- Not silo in just one function. Plenty of room to grow and expand your skills; just need to be ever ready to take up new challenges
- Employee's dedication and proven results will be recognised. There's performance review in place  which is good for a start-up
- Can wear casual to work, pantry has good supplies (more than biscuits and just 3-in-1 drink), free employee lunch and outings
- It's a booming industry; experience gained would be much appreciated by future employers
cons:
- Require high commitment and not suitable for ppl who emphasizes work-life balance
- Very lean set-up and don't have any additional backup for each role; you are responsible to set up a backup plan when you are away
- Performance-driven; can be quite stressful for ppl who don't like to deal with KPI and increasing challenges every month
- High frequency of ad hoc marketing activities and new campaigns
